description_narrative: Improving the protective environment for and self-reliance of affected populations across the Myanmar displacement axisPlease refer to DRC's Open Information Policy regarding publication of financial and project level data for this programme

- In Myanmar, displaced, marginalized, and conflict-affected people have the capacity and support to claim respect for, protection of, and fulfillment of their rights- At-risk communities in Myanmar have access to safe and comprehensive protection services- The basic needs of people in Myanmar are met-  People in Myanmar have more decent and sustainable livelihoods- In Myanmar and Bangladesh, local civil society organisations are more sustainable and able to support partners’ capacity, agency, and ability to leverage change and respond to needs

DRC allocated flexible funding to 4 countries in 2022 for a total of DKK 6,227,500, reaching 22,553 individuals. Countries supported were Burkina Faso, Mexico, Libya and Ethiopia. In addition to the allocation of flexible funding, DRC operations were supported by the deployment of roving emergency staff (EMPACT) and through the delivery of emergency training (EMCAP).

This grant is a top-up to the Danida SPA 2022-25. 20 month implementation period, this grant only covers 2022.fully flexible, can be reallocated to the current humanitarian situation and a Ukraine crisis

- Vulnerable populations linked to the Syrian crisis have improved access to rights and entitlements through legal aid and specialised protection services   Protection and legal information dissemination; Specialised Protection Services; Partnerships and Capacity Building - Improved self-reliance and resilience for host and Syrian refugee populations in the Middle East region through enhanced access to markets, and decent sustainable livelihoods in both urban and rural settingsSupport to home-based businesses and MSMEs to provide decent and resilient livelihoods- In the Middle East, local civil society have stronger capacity to coordinate, articulate, and advocate for durable solutions for those displaced by the Syrian crisis- People in the Middle East benefit from programmes more aligned with existing institutions, markets and state support systems, including safety nets and social protection systems, based on evidence for more effective sustainable solutions across the humanitarian development nexus

- Displaced and conflict affected people have their basic needs covered and are protected from violence, coercion and deprivation.  - DRC Libya, drawing upon internal resources such as the protection monitoring reports, will specifically work on strengthening people’s access to information on their rights and entitlements and reducing their vulnerabilities, support individuals to obtain documentation and legal aid, and provide opportunities for increased capacity and awareness to claim rights and to enable and support their social participation.- Displaced and conflict-affected people have access to goods, services, and income generating opportunities.
- Safer communities have the capacity and systems to reduce all forms of violence. - Refugees, returnees, IDPs and host communities have increased access to more decent and sustainable livelihoods.

title_narrative: DANIDA SPA 2023 Top-up Turkey Earthquake II
description_narrative: A massive earthquake (magnitude 7.8) with its epicentre near Gaziantep affected southern Turkey and northern Syria in the early hours of 6th February 2023. A series of aftershocks and subsequent earthquakes continue to cause large scale damage, loss of life and severe damage to infrastructure in the area. The areas in southern Türkiye host some of the largest populations of Syrian refugees – estimated to be approximately 3.7million in total across the country.Emergency services are still carrying out search and rescue operations (6th February, 1530h) in the affected areas, but initial reports indicate massive damage to housing stock, coming in the midst of extreme winter conditions in the area, and compounding existing severe economic and protection challenges being faced by both refugee and host populations.DRC’s Türkiye operation is headquartered in the city of Hatay – one of the worst affected areas, with its own field offices and bases, and partner presence across some of the areas most impacted by the earthquake – Kilis, Kahramanmarash, Sanliurfa and Antakya.While damage and need assessments are yet to be carried out, DRC has initiated response measures aimed at responding to what are likely to be most high priority needs. This is based on initial reports from the area and past experiences of responses to earthquakes. These include:

Syrian Regional Response- Vulnerable populations linked to the Syrian crisis have improved access to rights and entitlements through legal aid and specialised protection services   Psychosocial Support (PSS) and case management services provided to conflict- and displacement-affected children and their caregivers- Improved self-reliance and resilience for host and Syrian refugee populations in the Middle East region through enhanced access to markets, and decent sustainable livelihoods in both urban and rural settings- In the Middle East, local civil society have stronger capacity to coordinate, articulate, and advocate for durable solutions for those displaced by the Syrian crisis- People in the Middle East benefit from programmes more aligned with existing institutions, markets and state support systems, including safety nets and social protection systems, based on evidence for more effective sustainable solutions across the humanitarian development nexus

Emerging Shocks and Stresses in Lebanon- Children, women at risk and PWSNs are empowered to prevent risk factors related to their health and protection, while promoting positive health and protection outcomes- Children, women at risk and PWSN’s protection have been enhanced through access to specialized quality protection and economic recovery services

Syrian Regional Response- Vulnerable populations linked to the Syrian crisis have improved access to rights and entitlements through legal aid and specialised protection services   Decent and resilient livelihoods for refugees- Improved self-reliance and resilience for host and Syrian refugee populations in the Middle East region through enhanced access to markets, and decent sustainable livelihoods in both urban and rural settingsDecent and resilient livelihoods for refugees- In the Middle East, local civil society have stronger capacity to coordinate, articulate, and advocate for durable solutions for those displaced by the Syrian crisis- People in the Middle East benefit from programmes more aligned with existing institutions, markets and state support systems, including safety nets and social protection systems, based on evidence for more effective sustainable solutions across the humanitarian development nexus

- Increased adaptive capacities of agriculture and food market system actors through public-private cooperation, improved business models and best practices, results in improved productivity, growth, and sustainability of livelihoods in target conflict-affected communities in Iraq.- Vulnerable small-scale producers and small scale agro-enterprises in selected agriculture market systems have increased productivity and market competitiveness

title_narrative: DANIDA SPA 2022 HQ Stand by Roster
description_narrative: Part of the Danida SPA 2022 Flex Emergency TOC- People’s basic needs are metDRC allocated flexible funding to 4 countries in 2022 for a total of DKK 6,227,500, reaching 22,553 individuals. Countries supported were Burkina Faso, Mexico, Libya and Ethiopia. In addition to the allocation of flexible funding, DRC operations were supported by the deployment of roving emergency staff (EMPACT) and through the delivery of emergency training (EMCAP).
Integrated Programming Economic Recovery and Protection

1) People can claim respect for, protection of, and fulfilment of, their rights The protective environment of Burundian and Congolese refugee communities, and Burundian returnees has improved with better capacity to access, claim and fulfil their rights.Community-based protection groups are supported, and existing networks are strengthened- Protection risks and trends faced by refugees, IDPs, and returnees are identified through protection monitoring and advocacy tailored to programming is conducted- Case Management & one-off cash assistance are conducted2) People have more decent and resilient livelihoods Burundian and Congolese refugees, IDPs and host communities have increased resilience as a result of greater access to livelihoods and live more independently. - Community members have the livelihood skills and benefited vocational training- Right holders have benefited the advantages of permagarden- Right holders (Men and women) are economically empowered by cash for work assistance.- Right holders have received IGA and Start-up Kits
Policy, Programme and Strategy Support

The protection crisis in the Sahel is rooted in long term grievances of communities, weakened resilience systems due to insecurity and insufficient responses to the change in the ecosystems, fuelled by climate change, conflict, and changes in agro-pastoral practices.The response will strengthen local capacities on disaster preparedness and response, local rapid emergency responses and support locally grounded and climate adapted solutions (micro-projects) to prevent and mitigate negative impact of climate shocks and respond to humanitarian needs with a conflict sensitive approach.

title_narrative: Fair Recycling: an inclusive and formalised plastic recycling ecosystem in Kenya
description_narrative: The goal of the project is to integrate informal and marginalised waste pickers and refugee communities.in a formalised plastics recycling value chain - resulting in increased income -.decent jobs and safer work conditions. The project leverages the work of DRC and commercial.partners to implement innovative and financially sustainable impact-interventions in the value.chain - facilitating inclusive socio-economic growth opportunities and access to the formal.economy for waste pickers and refugee-communities..The project enables Unilever to access locally and fair recycled plastics of the highest quality -.driving the transition to a localized circular plastics economy Kenya (SDG 12). Formalisation.and growth of the Kenyan plastic recycling ecosystem supports Mr Green Africa’s work with.waste pickers to create sustainable and decent jobs (SDG 8) and do a way that effectively.reduces poverty (SDG 1) in a climate and environment-friendly manner (SDG 13).

The primary objective of this project is to provide comprehensive protection monitoring, mitigation and implementation services and interventions in complementary and integrated approach to address protection issues and mitigate negative coping mechanisms.
First line response to affected population in Las Canood

The project intends to pilot a local RRM led by national and/or local actors to respond to small and multi ple displacements. This project will focus on strengthening capacities of well-established and reputed lo cal responders to deliver life-saving assistance when and where crises strike, filling capacity gaps in emer gency preparedness and response while providing learning and good practices. The inclusive approach to partnership and coordination of the DRC localisation project in hard-to-reach Sahel hot spots will directly contribute to SRF strategy to deliver high quality VfM in Sahel hot spots. The project will contribute to the implementation of the localisation agenda in Sahel. Additionally, the learning of this project will inform the revision of the SRF strategy and framework to ensure national and local actors can play a more powerful role in the SRF governance structure and can directly access funds
